Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Small: Distributed Wireless Networking with An Enhanced Physical-Link Layer Interface

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The development of future wireless systems requires a network architecture that simultaneously addresses communication efficiency and system modularity. Due to the inefficiency of current network architectures, most existing networks adopt the structure of using wireless communication only at the last hop. The goal of this project is to develop an enhanced physical-link layer interface to solve the architectural inefficiency problem in wireless part of the special-structured networks, mainly for the distributed communication and networking model. By equipping a link layer user with multiple transmission options, the new interface enables advanced communication adaptation at the link layer that exploits wireless capabilities such as power, rate, and antenna adjustments. This project represents the first systematic investigation of distributed link layer networking that exploits multiple transmission options at each link layer user. The project will establish an important bridge toward the integration of information and network theories, and will serve as an example wireless architecture development that seeks to minimize its disturbance to the operation of wireline systems. Unification of information theory and network theory will also influence the way subjects are taught in Higher Education and attract more talented students to this field of acute national importance.

The project is organized into four steps. In Step I, the focus is to investigate typical distributed networking scenarios with homogeneous users and saturated message queues. Based on a stochastic approximation model, a medium access control (MAC) framework will be developed to enable effective formulation of distributed channel sharing problems. Distributed algorithms will be developed to ensure asymptotic optimal or near optimal performance with respect to the maximization of particular network utility functions. In Step II, the focus is to extend the MAC framework to distributed networks that contain user groups with different priorities, as well as to distributed cognitive networks where secondary users are required not to disturb the communications of the primary users. In Step III, the focus is to develop fast adaptive MAC algorithms by incorporating the exponential backing-off approach into the MAC framework. In Step IV, the focus is to use computer simulations to investigate performance of the MAC algorithms in practical scenarios.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The development of future wireless systems requires a network architecture that simultaneously addresses communication efficiency and system modularity. To solve the architectural inefficiency problem in wireless part of the networks, especially in distributed networks, we proposed an enhanced physical-link layer interface to equip each link layer user with multiple transmission options. Such an extension enabled advanced communication adaptation such as power, rate, and antenna adjustment at the data link layer, without destroying the layered network architecture.

In this project, we systematically investigated the problem of distributed physical layer and link layer networking that exploit multiple transmission options at each link layer user. At the physical layer, we completed the development of a distributed channel coding theory that allows each transmitter to arbitrarily choose a code to encode its message without sharing such a coding decision with other users or with the receiver. We officially defined and derived the distributed capacity of a channel, obtained achievable performance bounds in the cases of a finite codeword length, fading channels, as well as incomplete codebook and channel information. At the data link layer, we developed a distributed MAC algorithm that supports multiple transmission options at each user. The MAC algorithm associates each user with a transmission probability vector. Given an arbitrary symmetric network utility, and a general link layer channel model that is derived from the physical layer channel and the packet coding details, the distributed MAC algorithm can adapt the probability vectors to converge to a designed unique equilibrium that is close to optimal in the sense of maximizing the chosen utility. We also extended to distributed MAC algorithm to support a hierarchical primary-secondary user structure without requiring any direct information exchange between users.

This project established an important bridge toward the integration of information and network theories. The enhanced physical-link layer interface and its supporting theories serve as example wireless architecture developments that seek to improve communication and networking efficiency but also to maintain the layered network architecture, and consequently to minimize their disturbance to the operation of wireline systems. The project also helped in modernizing relevant courses in the ECE department at Colorado State University. Particularly, in graduate level course ECE516 (Information Theory), classical information theoretic results, the technical results from this project, as well as other life experiences are organized as examples to illustrate the approach of fundamental thinking.
